Updated Review
As requested by the developers in my comments I have now played the game again and I am updating my review accordingly. It's worth noting that this is written 9 days after the games release from Early Access - so supposedly a finished product.

The biggest change is that they have now fixed the fatal error bug that was making the game unplayable - I played the game for over 5 hours straight without a single crash. Crate auctions also now seem to work.

Unfortunately my assessment of the game remains the same, great idea, poorly implemented and now finally having been able to play it is my opinion that the gameplay itself lacks any substance.

Things that I believe are poorly implemented:
- The tutorial is awful, and even the biggest defenders of the game admit this. You can get the basics from it but its clunky.
- The UI / Menu system is also awful. Its particularly a problem for the tutorial where the tutorial instructions get obscured by pop up windows. In the actual game itself core functionality, such as saving, wanted lists, achivements / perks, missions / plot aren't accessible at all through a menu instead you need to use key bindings.
- One of the most common tasks you'll be doing in game is loading your transports with cargo and setting destinations and this is badly implemented, the interface for it is clunky and illogical requiring you to switch between a minimised window, but I also encountered a number of bugs where transports locations were incorrect i.e. listed as travelling when in fact in a country, and also when plotting the route only to find it thought the transport was in a different country. The pathing for the movement itself is also inconsistant e.g. its signigcantly quicker going from Russia to North Korea, than North Korea to Russia - as it takes a different route. Unless stationary your transports will more often than not appear as planes on the map, even after obviously traveling through a port and taking a sea route.
- There is no explanation of the target finder missions, and they are not built into the plot.
- The main story arc was broken for me when I purchased some discounted weapons but was intercepted causing me to automatically dump my stock so I couldnt complete the mission.
- The text e.g. no longer for sell" is either written by someone who has English as a second language or... well lets not go there.
- It looks like a whole bunch of stuff that was planned hasn't yet been implemented in game i.e. reputation system doesn't seem to have any impact (and isn't explained anywhere)

Ugh... I was so excited for this game, but it's from a new indie dev that isn't ready for primetime.  As other reviews have noted, the UI is painfully bad and sometimes counter-intuitive.  It's so early in development that all you can do is shuffle arms to make money. This game could theoretically get better, but right now I can't recommend it.

**RELEASE DAY UPDATE**

Bottom line up front:  Still underwhelming.

The UI has gotten better but is still not good.  The popup dialogs are still obtrusively large and don't close/minimize in a common sense kind of way.  The tutorial popup is particularly bad as it's opaque, unmovable and stays behind most the other popup dialogues.  The other UI element, the world map has gotten slightly better but is still lacking.  You still can't scroll the map at all (arrows, WASD, or mouse drag) and can only do point zooms with a scrollwheel. reviewText:
This is a great little game, but you need to understand what you are getting into.  I have two large warnings, I think you won't be happy if you are not comfortable with these:

- It is very much an indy title.  The interface is a bit rough, and sometimes difficult to interact with
- There are some bugs here and there, but the developers are responsive and a new patch just rolled out

The game is often described as a Business Simulator.  To be more specific, I liken it to a grown up version of the old DrugWars game.  Buy low, sell high, pay off your loans, evade the cops.

That is it in a nutshell.  Sounds simple, but there is a reason people still play DrugWars / DopeWars on every platform available:  It's a fun formula.  It replays well.

And Arms Dealer has a lot that it adds.:

- The variety of content and number of locations are huge.
- You have a wide selection of public and private transportation options.
- You can build and customize your transport vehicles
- You can involve yourself in global politics, and instigate wars to manipulate markets
- The metagame of evading law enforcement as well as headhunters adds a great layer of excitement

But I can't overemphasize my first two cautionary elements.  This is not a high-gloss title with millions of dollars behind its development.  It has some problems, and the interface can be a real challenge.  If you are easily frustrated or don't have the patience to learn something that is a bit counter-intuitive, this probably isn't for you.

reviewText:
Arms Dealer version 16.0.3

Subjectively, as someone who loves military hardware, trading sims, and political theatre, this game scratches all the right places.
All products, weaponry, have unique descriptions and stats that makes you weigh aspects like supply, capacity, distance, and per unit profit in each planned trade. The idea of being a shadowy merchant of death who bribes generals, puts nations to war, and sells every sort of imaginable weapon to make disgusting amounts of blood stained money while evading authorities is endearing and fun to role play. I love it. Because of my subjective enjoyment alone, I reccomend this game.

Objectively, the game shows promise, but needs a lot of work.
The interface gets in the way quite a bit. A prime example of this is travel. Say you want to move to Poland with a bunch of cheap machineguns from China. Click Poland right? Now you have a window for Poland. Ah! A travel tab! I want to take my private yacht so I'll click private travel. That....made a minimized window. Close the window for Poland. Unminimize. Poland is not selected. Choose private yacht. Now I have to click a button to plot course. Window minimizes. I can't click Poland, I need to click a chain of countries leading to Poland. That makes sense, some countries may have investigators or might not be paid off enough and could intercept my shipment. click click click. Okay, I have a path to Poland. Wait, I need to load my machineguns into the transport to be taken with me when I travel. Okay, got my machineguns loaded, I've told it to sell them instantly when I get there, I've bought intel to tell me how much profit per unit I'll make. Good to go. My yacht turns into a plane and flies through the countires I've plotted to Poland. There's a quick travel option too, but it never brings cargo and can take you on ridiculously inefficent paths, and a Public travel option which is great if you'd like to wait 7 minutes to go to one of 5 or so countries you've never heard of with 45 tons of Israeli pistols.

Several aspects of the game are incomplete or still being worked on, though it seems that they are being diligently updated by the developers. Some hidden menues don't do anything, a great portion of products are missing portrait graphics, Quite a few gameplay systems are implemented but seem to not be fully flushed out. There's definitely a lot of behind the scenes variables and factors that impact gameplay which are kept obscured from the player. The tutorial is also a slog you have to troubleshoot your way through.

Overall, I love the game personally, but you might not if you're not willing to tolerate its shortcomings. The game does show promise for future versions, but at the moment it can be a hassle to play through for someone who doesn't absolutely love the kind of game it is.

reviewText:
Lets be brutally honest here. This game is not the most beautiful game out there. Nor is it the most well polished game mechanically speaking. Sorry devs but that is just the truth. The game has its small issues. No dodging that.
But the good outweighs the bad tenfold.

I really dont want to write a wall of text. So i will bullet point the good and the bad and keep each one concise:

The good:
A simple UI that shows you what you need to know when you need to know it. It also looks nice enough.
A story mode that can be skipped. I dont know about you guys but i am not the biggest fan of story modes in a game like this. I like to just play. There is a nice sandbox mode which you can change the options for such as starting cash and so on.
Random events. A lot of games do this, of course, but this feels a little more random. It wont get to a point where you realise the random events are purely scripted and tyou can predict what will happen. Wars being the best example of this. Knowing that any nation can declare war on any other nation is actually kind of fun.
Freedom. Play your way. Different from story mode in that this applies to the game as a whole. You decide the best way to earn yourself money. Will you take advantage of the recent conflict that broke out? Will you decide to deal with only one part of the globe, perhaps only dealing in Asia or America? What form of transport will you use to smuggle your goods? Will you make an alliance with or destroy the competition? you get the idea.
Information, information,information, in a good way. The weapons you sell all have their own factoids. And some have been updated to suit the period the game is set in. And there is a good amount about your business. Everything you need to keep the money coming
Related to my last point, info is not free when it comes to supply and demand. There are mechanics in place that require you to pay for information about a country.
This game does not hold your hand. Once you have finished the tutorial you are on your own, for the most part.
Small point: Agencies hunting for you. There is a most wanted list in the game. Obviously you would expect it but this game does it quite well. There is a real need to keep an eye on the different agencies in the game.
Upcoming DLC that will expand the game into other criminal enterprises. Want to be the next Walter White? Well your meth labs are on their way :)The bad:
The tutorial is not the best ever. Sometimes it does not provide you with enough information. And worst of all its easy to break it if you accidentally stray from the tutorial or rush ahead a little and you will find yourself with a tutorial that no longer progresses.
Another small point: At this moment(without modding) you cant change things like your starting country. For me that was kind of irritating. I saw my Arms Dealer as a bit of a British gangster type.
I personally dont mind the feature i am about to mention but i understand why it is silly and would not mind if it changed. Odd countries going to war. Sometimes two countries will go to war that will make no sense. Sure its a game not real life, but its an immersion breaker sometimes.
I also noticed that some countries that would normally go to war with each other in a heartbeat are not available to choose when attempting to foster a war.
Thats about it for the bad list. There are features i would like to see. But nothing i would consider a let down for the game. Just personal preferences.

If the theme attracts you. And you like managment type games, you will like this game.
I know its said a lot but just keep in mind it is an indie title. Dont judge it by AAA standards.

reviewText: A few years back, I saw Lord of War for the first time. Nicholas Cage aside, the movie was fantastic. Watching other series such as Jormungand only served to heighten that interest. Something about the allure of traveling the globe selling weapons sucked me in; the money, the danger, the thrill of closing a deal, and the power looming behing it all. I have been looking for a game like Arms Dealer ever since, so needless to say I was thrilled when I found it on Steam. This game gives you the same power and control of an arms dealer. Nothing feels quite so satisfying as closing a multibillion dollar sale of AK-47s to Columbia while narrowly avoiding the law enforcement hot on your tail.\n\nThat said, this game is definitely not for everyone. It takes a certain amount of patience, so if you're looking for some kind of fast paced, Call-of-Duty esque game, look elsewhere. This IS a business management game, so managing the interface (which is incredibly detailed and takes some time to master) is just a part of what you're signing up for. Some negative reviews have called this counter-intuitive
date:
but for a game so large in scope, it is going to feel unwieldy at first until you learn to master it. Also on that note, the tutorial is... lacking, but despite that I still caught on fairly quickly.

Another aspect I would like to note is that yes, the game is still early on in the developmental stage. You can expect crashes, and my game save was erased whenever the game updated, forcing me to start from the beginning again. That said, I expected that coming in. This game is still early on in development. There are going to be bugs. None of these errors took away from my enjoyment playing the game, and from the way I've seen this developer work, I have faith that this will get fixed in a timely manner.

In short, know what you are signing up for: you will be getting into a detailed, entertaining management game where you feel like a badass mastermind, and as the game is still being worked on and updated, you as a community member have a huge say in how the game moves forward.

If you have a few bucks to spare and are a fan of Lord of War, Jormungand, or feeling like a global badass, this game is certainly worth it.

reviewText:
Honest review time, at the current stage I can really tell that it will be a decent game in a couple of months but as of March and the beginning of April it isn't really that great. I recommend to play it once, wait a couple of months, then try it again.

I haven't been the one to play tycoon/sim games, the only other tycoon I have played other than flash games was Video Game Dev, and I thought it was swell. As far as I know, to my knowledge there are not any other games like this. I have close to 300 games so hopefully that entitles me to review this. I'm going to try a Pros/Cons list.

This one time in Russian Nuclear Blast camp, Yuri Orlov bought 400 AK-47s and Russia couldn't defend itself from Wheat Warriors.

Pros:
+Original concept
+Large arsenal to buy and sell
+Mod support (Lord of War mod)
+Endless scenarios for conflict
+Dev team activley works to fix bugs and improve the overall experience
+Sandbox options make replayability a possibility
+You can now name your character, so name yourself Yuri Orlov.
+A fun experience to actively participate in making history by selling weapons to either or both sides of an armed conflict.

Cons:
-Some countries are still not accessable (Notably Austria being merged with Switzerland)
-Learning curve is not too too steep, but unless you play the tutorial you may not make much progress.
-UI is meh
-Story is non-existent
-Some windows such as the Wanted Persons or the News window do not have an accessible button fromt the map, instead you have to open the controls and look up the hotkey.
-Transportation is meh (You can build new vehicles with futuristic addons but travelling in anything other than your yacht is annoying and slow.)

April 2, 2015
